Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the likelihood of a bubonic plague epidemic by stating that it is "likely to trigger severe epidemic" according to the WHO, when in fact the WHO has stated that the reported case is "being well managed" and not considered high-risk.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by stating that the bubonic plague can be spread via cough droplets, when in fact the CDC states that the bubonic plague usually results from the bite of an infected flea and that the pneumonic plague is the only form that can be spread from person to person through infectious droplets.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any direct quotes or official statements from the WHO or CDC to back up its claims.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the reported case of bubonic plague in China will trigger a severe epidemic, despite the WHO stating that it is being well managed and not considered high-risk.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no evidence of alternative explanation bias in the provided claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the reported case of bubonic plague in China is being well managed, as stated by the WHO.
